docs.text: Docker ⚓︎ Helpful Docker Commands ⚓︎ Below are some less-common Docker commands you might find useful. Get Runtime Statistics ⚓︎ 1 docker stats $( docker ps --format = '{{.Names}}' ) This command will display detailed information about the docker containers you have running locally including: Container Name Name CPU % Memory Usage/Limit Memory % Network I/O Block Storage I/O Process IDs Remove All Stopped Containers ⚓︎ 1 docker rm $( docker ps -a -q ) If you have a lot of stopped containers (perhaps you didn't supply a container name when running images), you can run this command to automatically remove all stopped containers. Remove Untagged Containers ⚓︎ 1 docker images -q --filter "dangling=true" | xargs docker rmi Prune Everything ⚓︎ 1 docker system prune --volumes This command will remove all unused: Containers Images (dangling & unused) Networks (Optionally) Volumes Note If you do not want to prune volumes, remove --volumes from the command above.
docs.title: Docker

docs.text: Below are some less-common Docker commands you might find useful.
docs.title: Helpful Docker Commands

docs.text: 1 docker stats $( docker ps --format = '{{.Names}}' ) This command will display detailed information about the docker containers you have running locally including: Container Name Name CPU % Memory Usage/Limit Memory % Network I/O Block Storage I/O Process IDs
docs.title: Get Runtime Statistics

docs.text: 1 docker rm $( docker ps -a -q ) If you have a lot of stopped containers (perhaps you didn't supply a container name when running images), you can run this command to automatically remove all stopped containers.
docs.title: Remove All Stopped Containers

docs.text: 1 docker system prune --volumes This command will remove all unused: Containers Images (dangling & unused) Networks (Optionally) Volumes Note If you do not want to prune volumes, remove --volumes from the command above.
docs.title: Prune Everything
